label: DatadogApi
description: Tools that enable LLMs to interact directly with the Datadog API.

tools.name: AcknowledgeOnCallPage
tools.description:
Acknowledge an On-Call Page alert in Datadog.

Use this tool to acknowledge an On-Call Page alert for a specified page in Datadog. This can be used to indicate that an alert is being addressed.

parameters.name: on_call_page_id
parameters.description: The unique identifier for the On-Call Page to acknowledge.

tools.name: ActivateAwsScanOptions
tools.description: Activate Agentless scan options for an AWS account.

parameters.name: aws_account_id
parameters.description: The ID of the AWS account for which to activate scan options.

parameters.name: enable_container_vulnerability_scanning
parameters.description: Enable scanning for vulnerabilities in containers when set to true.

parameters.name: enable_lambda_function_scanning
parameters.description: Enable scanning of Lambda functions. Set to true to enable, false to disable.

parameters.name: enable_sensitive_data_scanning
parameters.description: Indicates if scanning for sensitive data is enabled for the AWS account.

parameters.name: enable_vulnerability_scan_host_os
parameters.description: Indicates if scanning for vulnerabilities in host operating systems is enabled.

parameters.name: resource_type
parameters.description: Specifies the resource type to activate. Must be 'aws_scan_options'.

tools.name: ActivateAzureScanOptions
tools.description:
Activate Agentless scan options for Azure subscriptions.

Use this tool to activate Agentless scan options for a specified Azure subscription. This is useful for enabling security scans without deploying agents.

parameters.name: azure_subscription_id
parameters.description: The Azure subscription ID for which to activate the scan options.

parameters.name: enable_container_vulnerability_scan
parameters.description: Set to true to activate scanning for vulnerabilities in containers.

parameters.name: enable_vulnerability_scan_hosts
parameters.description: Indicate if scanning for vulnerabilities in Azure hosts is enabled. Set to true to activate.

parameters.name: resource_type
parameters.description: Specifies the resource type. Always use 'azure_scan_options'.

tools.name: ActivateGcpScanOptions
tools.description:
Activate Agentless scan options for a GCP project.

Use this tool to enable Agentless scanning for a Google Cloud Platform project. This is useful for setting up security scans without deploying agents.

parameters.name: enable_container_vulnerability_scanning
parameters.description: Set to true to enable scanning for vulnerabilities in containers.

parameters.name: enable_vulnerability_host_scanning
parameters.description: Set to true to enable scanning for vulnerabilities in hosts in the GCP project.

parameters.name: gcp_project_id
parameters.description: The Google Cloud Platform project ID for which to activate the scan options.

parameters.name: gcp_scan_resource_type
parameters.description: The type of GCP scan options resource. This is typically 'gcp_scan_options'.

tools.name: AddCommentToCase
tools.description:
Add a comment to a specific case in Datadog.

Use this tool to post a comment to a particular case within the Datadog system by providing the case ID.

parameters.name: case_identifier
parameters.description: The unique identifier (UUID or key) for the case to which the comment will be added.

parameters.name: comment_message
parameters.description: The message content to be added as a comment on the case.

parameters.name: case_resource_type
parameters.description: Specify the type of resource, always set to 'case'.

comment_message.value: This is an updated comment regarding the ongoing investigation.

tools.name: AddDashboardsToList
tools.description:
Add dashboards to an existing list in Datadog.

    Use this tool to append dashboards to a specified existing dashboard list in Datadog. Ideal for organizing and managing dashboards effectively.

    Note: Understanding the request schema is necessary to properly create
    the stringified JSON input object for execution.

This operation also requires path parameters.

    Modes:
    - GET_REQUEST_SCHEMA: Returns the schema. Only call if you don't
      already have it. Do NOT call repeatedly if you already received
      the schema.
    - EXECUTE: Performs the operation with the provided request body
      JSON.
      Note: You must also provide the required path parameters when executing.

    If you need the schema, call with mode='get_request_schema' ONCE, then execute.

parameters.name: mode
parameters.description: Operation mode: 'get_request_schema' returns the OpenAPI spec for the request body, 'execute' performs the actual operation

parameters.name: dashboard_list_identifier
parameters.description: Specify the integer ID of the dashboard list where dashboards will be added.  Required when mode is 'execute', ignored when mode is 'get_request_schema'.

parameters.name: request_body
parameters.description: Stringified JSON representing the request body. Required when mode is 'execute', ignored when mode is 'get_request_schema'

tools.name: AddMemberTeamToSuperTeam
tools.description:
Add a member team to a super team.

Use this tool to add a specified team as a member of an existing super team by providing the super team's ID.

parameters.name: member_team_identifier
parameters.description: The unique identifier of the member team to be added to the super team.

parameters.name: super_team_identifier
parameters.description: The ID of the super team to which the member team will be added. It is a string value.

parameters.name: member_team_type
parameters.description: Specifies the type of member team to be added. Must be 'member_teams'.

tools.name: AddPermissionToRole
tools.description:
Assigns a specific permission to a given role.

Use this tool to add a permission to a specific role within Datadog. It should be called when you need to assign new permissions to a role to adjust user access and capabilities.

parameters.name: role_identifier
parameters.description: The unique identifier of the role to which the permission will be added.

parameters.name: permission_id
parameters.description: ID of the permission to be added to the role.

parameters.name: permissions_resource_type
parameters.description: The resource type for the permission, should be 'permissions'.

tools.name: AddReadRoleToArchive
tools.description:
Adds a read role to a specified archive.

Use this tool to grant read access to a specific archive by adding a read role. Ideal for managing permissions and ensuring the right users or groups have access to log data archives.

parameters.name: archive_id
parameters.description: The unique identifier for the archive to which a read role will be added. This is required to specify the target archive for access management.

parameters.name: role_type
parameters.description: The type of role to be added. Must be 'roles'.

parameters.name: role_unique_identifier
parameters.description: The unique identifier for the role to be added to the archive.

tools.name: AddRoleToRestrictionQuery
tools.description:
Adds a role to a restriction query for logs configuration.

This tool is used to add a specific role to an existing restriction query in Datadog's logs configuration. Call this tool when you need to update restriction queries by including additional roles.

parameters.name: restriction_query_id
parameters.description: The ID of the restriction query to which a role will be added.

parameters.name: role_type
parameters.description: The type of the role, expected to be 'roles'.

parameters.name: role_unique_identifier
parameters.description: The unique identifier of the role to be added to the restriction query.

tools.name: AddTeamLink
tools.description:
Add a new link to a Datadog team.

Use this tool to add a new link to a specific team's page in Datadog. Suitable for enhancing team resources or documentation by linking additional references.

parameters.name: link_label
parameters.description: The label for the link to be added to the team. This should be a descriptive text for the link.

parameters.name: link_url
parameters.description: The URL to be added as a link for the team. This should be a valid web address.

parameters.name: target_team_id
parameters.description: The unique identifier for the team to which the link will be added.

parameters.name: link_position
parameters.description: The position of the link in the team's list, used for sorting links.

parameters.name: team_id_for_link
parameters.description: ID of the team the link is associated with. This should be a unique identifier for the specific team to which you want to add the link.

parameters.name: team_link_type
parameters.description: Specify the type of team link. Must be 'team_links'.

tools.name: AddUserToRole
tools.description:
Adds a user to a specific role in Datadog.

Use this tool to add a user to a specific role in Datadog's system. It is called when you need to assign user permissions via roles.

parameters.name: role_unique_identifier
parameters.description: The unique identifier for the role you want to assign the user to.

parameters.name: user_unique_identifier
parameters.description: A unique identifier representing the user to be added to the role.

parameters.name: users_resource_type
parameters.description: Specifies the type of resource as 'users'. Always use 'users'.

tools.name: AddUserToTeam
tools.description:
Add a user to a team in Datadog.

Use this tool to add a specified user to an existing team within Datadog by providing the team ID.

parameters.name: team_id
parameters.description: The ID of the team to which the user will be added. This is required to specify the target team.

parameters.name: provisioned_user_or_service_account_id
parameters.description: UUID of the User or Service Account who provisioned the team membership, or null if done via SAML mapping.

parameters.name: provisioning_mechanism
parameters.description: Mechanism responsible for provisioning the team relationship. Possible values: null for user-added, "service_account" for service account, "saml_mapping" for SAML mapping.

parameters.name: team_identifier
parameters.description: The unique ID of the team to which the user will be added.

parameters.name: team_membership_type
parameters.description: Specify the type of team membership. Use 'team_memberships'.

parameters.name: user_id
parameters.description: The ID of the user to be added to the team in Datadog.

parameters.name: user_role_in_team
parameters.description: Specifies the user's role within the team. Currently, only 'admin' is supported as a role.

parameters.name: user_team_type
parameters.description: Specifies the type for the team relationship, fixed as 'team'.

parameters.name: user_team_user_type
parameters.description: Set to 'users' as the type for the user in the team.

tools.name: AggregateLogs
tools.description:
Aggregate logs to compute metrics and timeseries.

This tool aggregates log events into buckets to compute relevant metrics and timeseries. It's useful for analyzing large volumes of log data to extract meaningful insights.

Note: Understanding the request schema is necessary to properly create
the stringified JSON input object for execution.

Modes:
- GET_REQUEST_SCHEMA: Returns the schema. Only call if you don't
  already have it. Do NOT call repeatedly if you already received
  the schema.
- EXECUTE: Performs the operation with the provided request body
  JSON.

If you need the schema, call with mode='get_request_schema' ONCE, then execute.

parameters.name: mode
parameters.description: Operation mode: 'get_request_schema' returns the OpenAPI spec for the request body, 'execute' performs the actual operation

parameters.name: request_body
parameters.description: Stringified JSON representing the request body. Required when mode is 'execute', ignored when mode is 'get_request_schema'

tools.description:

tools.name: AggregateSpansMetrics
tools.description:
Aggregate spans to compute metrics and timeseries.

Use this tool to aggregate spans into buckets and compute metrics and timeseries data. This is useful for analyzing performance and trends in systems. Note: Limited to 300 requests per hour.

Note: Understanding the request schema is necessary to properly create
the stringified JSON input object for execution.

Modes:

tools.description:
Aggregate CI Visibility test events into metrics and timeseries.

Use this tool to aggregate CI test events into buckets for computed metrics and timeseries insights.

Note: Understanding the request schema is necessary to properly create

tools.name: ArchiveAzureCostAccount
tools.description:
Archive an Azure Cloud Cost Management account in Datadog.

Use this tool to archive a Cloud Cost Management account associated with Azure in Datadog. This action is irreversible and should be performed when you need to remove cost management configurations for a specific Azure account.

parameters.name: azure_cloud_account_id
parameters.description: The ID of the Azure Cloud Cost Management account to archive. This is necessary to identify which account's configurations will be removed.

tools.name: ArchiveCase
tools.description:
Archive a specific case in Datadog.

This tool is used to archive a case in Datadog by specifying the case ID. Call this tool when you need to move a case to the archive for record-keeping or compliance.

parameters.name: case_unique_id
parameters.description: The unique identifier or key of the case to be archived in Datadog.

parameters.name: case_resource_type
parameters.description: Specify 'case' as the resource type to identify the case resource.

tools.name: ArchiveCloudCostAccount
tools.description:
Archive a Cloud Cost Management Account.

Use this tool to archive a Cloud Cost Management Account in Datadog, specifically for AWS CUR configurations. Useful for managing or removing outdated or unnecessary cost configurations.

parameters.name: cloud_account_id
parameters.description: The unique identifier for the Cloud Account to be archived in Datadog.

tools.name: ArchiveGcpCostManagementAccount
tools.description:
Archive a Cloud Cost Management account.

Use this tool to archive a Google Cloud Platform (GCP) cost management account in Datadog.

parameters.name: cloud_account_identifier
parameters.description: The unique identifier for the GCP cloud account to be archived.

tools.name: AssignCaseToUser
tools.description:
Assign a case to a specific user.

Use this tool to assign a case to a specific user by providing the case ID. It should be called when you need to allocate a case to an appropriate team member or user.

parameters.name: assignee_user_id
parameters.description: The UUID of the user to whom the case will be assigned.

parameters.name: case_id
parameters.description: The unique identifier (UUID or key) of the case to be assigned.

parameters.name: case_resource_type
parameters.description: Specify the resource type. Must be set to 'case'.

tools.name: BulkDeleteDatastoreItems
tools.description:
Delete multiple items from a datastore at once.

Use this tool to delete multiple items from a specified datastore by their keys in a single operation. It's ideal for efficiently removing batches of entries when managing datastore contents.

parameters.name: datastore_identifier
parameters.description: The unique ID of the datastore from which items will be deleted.

parameters.name: datastore_items_id
parameters.description: ID for the datastore of items you want to delete.

parameters.name: item_keys_to_delete
parameters.description: List of up to 100 primary keys identifying items to delete from the datastore.

parameters.name: items_resource_type
parameters.description: Specifies the resource type of the items. Must be 'items'.

tools.name: BulkUpdateDatastoreItems
tools.description:
Perform bulk creation or replacement of datastore items.

    Use this tool to create or replace multiple items in a Datadog datastore in a single operation by specifying their keys.

    Note: Understanding the request schema is necessary to properly create
    the stringified JSON input object for execution.

This operation also requires path parameters.

    Modes:
    - GET_REQUEST_SCHEMA: Returns the schema. Only call if you don't
      already have it. Do NOT call repeatedly if you already received
      the schema.
    - EXECUTE: Performs the operation with the provided request body
      JSON.
      Note: You must also provide the required path parameters when executing.

    If you need the schema, call with mode='get_request_schema' ONCE, then execute.

parameters.name: mode
parameters.description: Operation mode: 'get_request_schema' returns the OpenAPI spec for the request body, 'execute' performs the actual operation

parameters.name: datastore_identifier
parameters.description: The unique identifier for the datastore where items will be updated or replaced.  Required when mode is 'execute', ignored when mode is 'get_request_schema'.

parameters.name: request_body
parameters.description: Stringified JSON representing the request body. Required when mode is 'execute', ignored when mode is 'get_request_schema'

tools.name: CancelDowntime
tools.description:
Cancel an active downtime in Datadog.

Use this tool to cancel an active downtime in Datadog. The downtime remains visible for about two days in search results until it is permanently removed.

parameters.name: downtime_id
parameters.description: Provide the ID of the downtime you wish to cancel.

tools.name: CancelHistoricalJob
tools.description:
Cancel a historical job in Datadog.

Use this tool to cancel an ongoing historical job in Datadog, identified by its job ID.

parameters.name: job_id
parameters.description: The unique identifier of the historical job to be canceled in Datadog.

tools.name: CancelWorkflowInstance
tools.description:
Cancel a specific execution of a workflow.

Use this tool to cancel a specific execution of a given workflow in Datadog. Ensure you have the necessary application key or permissions configured to perform this action.

parameters.name: workflow_id
parameters.description: The unique ID of the workflow to cancel. It must be a valid string as per the API specifications.

parameters.name: workflow_instance_id
parameters.description: The unique identifier of the workflow instance to be canceled.

tools.name: ChangeSignalState
tools.description:
Change the triage state of a security signal.

This tool is used to modify the triage state of a specific security signal in Datadog's security monitoring system. It is useful for managing signal priorities and responses.

parameters.name: new_triage_state
parameters.description: The new triage state of the signal. Valid options are 'open', 'archived', or 'under_review'.

parameters.name: signal_id
parameters.description: The unique identifier of the security signal to be updated.

parameters.name: archive_comment
parameters.description: Optional comment to display on archived signals. Useful for context or documentation.

parameters.name: archive_reason
parameters.description: Reason for archiving the signal. Options include 'none', 'false_positive', 'testing_or_maintenance', 'investigated_case_opened', or 'other'.

parameters.name: event_type
parameters.description: The type of event, must be 'signal_metadata'.

parameters.name: security_signal_unique_id
parameters.description: The unique identifier for the security signal to be modified.

parameters.name: updated_signal_version
parameters.description: The version number of the signal to update. The update is rejected if the server's version is higher.

archive_comment.value: Review needed for potential false positive.

tools.name: CloneExistingRole
tools.description:
Clone an existing role based on role ID.

This tool allows cloning of an existing role by using its unique role ID. It should be called when you need to create a duplicate of an existing role with identical permissions.

parameters.name: new_role_name
parameters.description: Name of the new role that is cloned from an existing role.

parameters.name: role_unique_identifier
parameters.description: The unique identifier of the role to be cloned.

parameters.name: role_type
parameters.description: Specifies the type of role for the clone operation. Must be 'roles'.

tools.name: ConfigureBulkTagsForMetrics
tools.description:
Configure bulk tags for specified metrics in Datadog.

Use this tool to create and define queryable tag keys for existing count, gauge, rate, and distribution metrics in Datadog by specifying a metric name prefix. It manages tags configurations and sends results to account email addresses. Suitable for users with 'Manage Tags for Metrics' permission.

parameters.name: metric_name_prefix
parameters.description: A text prefix used to match against metric names for bulk tags configuration.

parameters.name: actively_queried_tags_window_seconds
parameters.description: Time window in seconds for configuring actively queried tags for matching metrics. Minimum is 1 second, maximum is 7,776,000 seconds (90 days).

parameters.name: exclude_configured_tags
parameters.description: Set to true to exclude configured tags and include all other tags. Defaults to false.

parameters.name: metric_bulk_configure_tags_resource
parameters.description: The resource identifier for configuring bulk tags for metrics. Must be set to 'metric_bulk_configure_tags'.

parameters.name: notification_emails
parameters.description: A list of account emails to notify when the configuration is applied.

parameters.name: override_existing_configurations
parameters.description: Set to true to override any existing configurations for the metric with the new tags. Defaults to true.

parameters.name: tags_to_apply
parameters.description: A list of tag names to apply to the metric configuration in Datadog.

tools.name: ConvertJobResultToSignal
tools.description:
Convert a job result to a signal for detection purposes.

Use this tool to transform a job result into a signal, useful for detection and monitoring in Datadog.

parameters.name: job_result_ids
parameters.description: Array of job result IDs to convert into signals.

parameters.name: notifications_sent
parameters.description: List of notification types sent related to the signal.

parameters.name: payload_type
parameters.description: Type of payload, must be 'historicalDetectionsJobResultSignalConversion'.

parameters.name: request_id
parameters.description: A unique identifier for the request that is used to convert the job result to a signal.

parameters.name: signal_message
parameters.description: Message content of the generated signals to be converted.

parameters.name: signal_severity
parameters.description: Severity level of the security signal. Accepts values: info, low, medium, high, critical.

tools.name: ConvertRuleJsonToTerraform
tools.description:
Converts Datadog security rules from JSON to Terraform format.

Use this tool to convert a Datadog security monitoring rule from JSON format to Terraform format. It is helpful when you need to transform security rules for infrastructure as code purposes.

Note: Understanding the request schema is necessary to properly create
the stringified JSON input object for execution.

Modes:
- GET_REQUEST_SCHEMA: Returns the schema. Only call if you don't
  already have it. Do NOT call repeatedly if you already received
  the schema.
- EXECUTE: Performs the operation with the provided request body
  JSON.

If you need the schema, call with mode='get_request_schema' ONCE, then execute.

parameters.name: mode
parameters.description: Operation mode: 'get_request_schema' returns the OpenAPI spec for the request body, 'execute' performs the actual operation

parameters.name: request_body
parameters.description: Stringified JSON representing the request body. Required when mode is 'execute', ignored when mode is 'get_request_schema'

tools.name: ConvertSecurityRuleToTerraform
tools.description:
Convert existing security rule from JSON to Terraform.

This tool converts an existing Datadog security monitoring rule from its JSON format to a Terraform configuration. Use it to facilitate the integration and management of your rules using Terraform.

parameters.name: rule_id
parameters.description: The ID of the Datadog security monitoring rule to convert.

tools.name: CreateActionConnection
tools.description:
Create a new action connection in Datadog.

Use this tool to create a new action connection in Datadog. Ensure you have a registered application key before using this tool.

Note: Understanding the request schema is necessary to properly create
the stringified JSON input object for execution.

Modes:
- GET_REQUEST_SCHEMA: Returns the schema. Only call if you don't
  already have it. Do NOT call repeatedly if you already received
  the schema.
- EXECUTE: Performs the operation with the provided request body
  JSON.

If you need the schema, call with mode='get_request_schema' ONCE, then execute.

parameters.name: mode
parameters.description: Operation mode: 'get_request_schema' returns the OpenAPI spec for the request body, 'execute' performs the actual operation

parameters.name: request_body
parameters.description: Stringified JSON representing the request body. Required when mode is 'execute', ignored when mode is 'get_request_schema'

tools.name: CreateApmRetentionFilter
tools.description:
Create a retention filter for indexing spans in Datadog.

Use this tool to create a retention filter in Datadog that indexes spans within your organization. Note that default filters of types spans-errors-sampling-processor and spans-appsec-sampling-processor cannot be created. This tool returns the definition of the newly created retention filter.

parameters.name: enable_retention_filter
parameters.description: Set to true to enable the retention filter or false to disable it.

parameters.name: retention_filter_name
parameters.description: The name for the retention filter to be created.

parameters.name: search_query
parameters.description: The search query using span search syntax to define criteria for retention.

parameters.name: span_sample_rate
parameters.description: Sample rate for spans matching the query. A value of 1.0 processes all matching spans.

parameters.name: resource_type
parameters.description: Specify the type of the resource, always use 'apm_retention_filter'.

parameters.name: retention_filter_type
parameters.description: Set the type of retention filter. Must be 'spans-sampling-processor'.

parameters.name: trace_sample_rate
parameters.description: Sample rate for traces with spans going through the filter. Use 1.0 to keep all matching traces.

tools.name: CreateAuthnMapping
tools.description:
Creates a new AuthN Mapping in Datadog.

This tool calls the Datadog API to create a new AuthN Mapping. It should be used when you need to set up or configure authentication mappings in Datadog.

Note: Understanding the request schema is necessary to properly create

parameters.description: Stringified JSON representing the request body. Required when mode is 'execute', ignored when mode is 'get_request_schema'

tools.name: CreateAwsAccountIntegration
tools.description:
Create a new AWS Account Integration Config in Datadog.

This tool should be called when you need to integrate an AWS account with Datadog. It will set up a new AWS account configuration for monitoring and managing AWS services through Datadog.

Note: Understanding the request schema is necessary to properly create

Modes:

tools.name: CreateAwsCurConfig
tools.description:
Create an AWS CUR config for Cloud Cost Management.

Use this tool to create a Cloud Cost Management account for an AWS Cost and Usage Report (CUR) configuration.

parameters.name: aws_account_id
parameters.description: The AWS account ID for which the CUR config is created. This is required to specify which AWS account the configuration applies to.

parameters.name: aws_bucket_name_for_cur

Use this tool to retrieve a specific Custom Costs file from Datadog by providing the file ID.

parameters.name: file_identifier
parameters.description: A unique identifier for the Custom Costs file to be retrieved from Datadog.

tools.name: FetchDashboardListItems
tools.description:
Fetch details of dashboards in a list.

parameters.name: dashboard_list_id
parameters.description: The unique integer ID of the dashboard list from which to retrieve dashboard definitions.

tools.name: FetchGcpScanOptions

tools.name: FetchMonthlyCostAttribution
tools.description:
Retrieve monthly cost attribution data by tag.

Fetch detailed monthly cost attribution by tag for both multi-org and single root-org accounts. Use this to track and report cost allocations within an organization after the 19th of each month. Ensure to handle pagination if necessary to acquire all records.

parameters.name: cost_types_fields
parameters.description: Comma-separated list specifying cost types and proportions. Use `*` to retrieve all fields. Example: `infra_host_on_demand_cost,infra_host_percentage_in_account`.

parameters.name: start_month
parameters.description: Datetime in ISO-8601 format, UTC, precise to month `[YYYY-MM]`. Represents the start of the costing period.

parameters.name: end_month
parameters.description: The final month for cost calculation. Use ISO-8601 format `[YYYY-MM]` to specify the month.

parameters.name: include_child_organization_costs
parameters.description: Include child organization costs in the response. Defaults to true.

parameters.name: pagination_next_record_id
parameters.description: Identifier for fetching the next set of results in a paginated response. Use the 'next_record_id' from the previous response.

parameters.name: sort_by_billing_dimension
parameters.description: Billing dimension to sort by. Defaults to sorting by total cost. Example: 'infra_host'.

parameters.name: sort_by_direction
parameters.description: Specifies the direction to sort cost attribution data. Use 'desc' for descending or 'asc' for ascending order.

parameters.name: tag_keys_for_cost_grouping
parameters.description: Comma-separated list of tag keys used to group costs. If empty, costs won't be grouped by tag. Check `tag_config_source` in the API response for available tags.

tools.name: FetchRecentAwsOnDemandTasks
tools.description:
Retrieve the latest AWS on demand tasks.

Fetches the most recent 1000 AWS on demand tasks. Useful for monitoring or analyzing recent AWS activities managed by Datadog.

tools.name: FetchScorecardRules
tools.description:
Fetch all scorecard rules from Datadog.

Use this tool to retrieve a list of all scorecard rules from Datadog's API. This is useful for managing and reviewing rules related to scorecards.

parameters.name: filter_custom_rules_only
parameters.description: Set to true to include only custom rules in the results.

parameters.name: filter_for_enabled_rules
parameters.description: Set to true to filter for enabled rules only.

parameters.name: filter_rule_by_id
parameters.description: Filter the rules based on a specific rule ID.

parameters.name: filter_rule_description
parameters.description: Filter rules based on their description. Provide a string to match against the rule descriptions.

parameters.name: filter_rules_by_name
parameters.description: Specify a rule name to filter the scorecard rules.

parameters.name: include_scorecard_details
parameters.description: Specify related scorecard details to include in the response.

parameters.name: page_offset
parameters.description: Specific offset to use as the beginning of the returned page for fetching scorecard rules.

parameters.name: page_size
parameters.description: Number of rules to return per page. Maximum value is 100.

parameters.name: specific_rule_fields
parameters.description: Specify which rule fields to include in the response. Provide a comma-separated list of field names.

parameters.name: specific_scorecard_fields
parameters.description: Specify which fields to include in the response for scorecard attributes. Use comma-separated values.

tools.name: FindSecurityAlerts
tools.description:

parameters.name: maximum_timestamp_for_signals

parameters.name: minimum_timestamp

parameters.name: pagination_cursor

parameters.name: search_query_for_security_signals
parameters.description: Search query to filter and list specific security signals. Use keywords and operators to refine results.

parameters.name: sort_order
parameters.description: The criteria for sorting security signals, either 'timestamp' or '-timestamp'.

parameters.name: group_by_fields
parameters.description: Comma-separated list of fields to group connections by, with a maximum of 10 fields.

parameters.name: start_time_unix_timestamp
parameters.description: Unix timestamp for the start of the query window. Defaults to 15 minutes before `end_time_unix_timestamp` if not provided.

tools.name: GetAggregatedDnsTraffic
tools.description:
Retrieve all aggregated DNS traffic data.

parameters.description: Unix timestamp (seconds since epoch) for the end of the query window. Defaults to current time if not provided.

parameters.name: filter_dns_traffic_by_tags

parameters.name: max_dns_entries
parameters.description: Number of aggregated DNS entries to return, up to a maximum of 7500. Default is 100.

parameters.name: start_query_timestamp
parameters.description: Unix timestamp for the query window start. Defaults to 15 min before `to` timestamp if not specified.

tools.description:
Retrieve details of a specific downtime by ID.

tools.name: GetEstimatedCostDatadog
tools.description:
Retrieve estimated cost data for multi-org Datadog accounts.

This tool retrieves the estimated cost for the current and previous month across multi-org and single root-org Datadog accounts. The data is only available for parent-level organizations and is delayed by up to 72 hours.

parameters.name: cost_end_month
parameters.description: Specify the ending month for the estimated cost in ISO-8601 format, UTC (`[YYYY-MM]`).

parameters.name: cost_view_level
parameters.description: Specify if cost is broken down at the parent-org level (summary) or sub-org level (sub-org). Defaults to summary.

parameters.name: end_date
parameters.description: Specify the end date for cost estimation in ISO-8601 format (YYYY-MM-DD). It marks the last day of the period for which you need cost data.

parameters.name: include_connected_accounts
parameters.description: Include accounts connected as partner customers in Datadog's partner network program. Defaults to `false`.

parameters.name: initial_cost_month
parameters.description: ISO-8601 month format `[YYYY-MM]`, specifying the start month for cost data. Cannot be older than two months. Provide `end_month` for month-over-month cost.

parameters.name: start_date_for_cost
parameters.description: Datetime in ISO-8601 format, UTC, precise to day: `[YYYY-MM-DD]` for cost beginning this day. Either specify `start_date_for_cost` or `start_month_for_cost`, but not both. The date cannot be more than two months in the past. Use with `end_date_for_cost` for cumulative day-over-day cost.

tools.name: GetEventDetails
tools.description:
Retrieve detailed information about a specific event.

Use this tool to get detailed information about an event by providing its unique event ID. It is useful for obtaining specifics about incidents or activities tracked in Datadog.

parameters.name: event_unique_id

Retrieves detailed information for a specific Fastly account.

Retrieve Fastly service details for a specific account.

Call this tool to get information about a Fastly service linked to a Datadog account using the account ID and the service ID.

parameters.name: fastly_account_id

parameters.name: fastly_service_id

tools.name: GetFutureRuleSuppressions
tools.description:
Retrieve suppressions affecting a future security rule.

Use this tool to get a list of suppressions that would impact a specified security monitoring rule in the future.

Note: Understanding the request schema is necessary to properly create
the stringified JSON input object for execution.

Modes:
- GET_REQUEST_SCHEMA: Returns the schema. Only call if you don't
  already have it. Do NOT call repeatedly if you already received
  the schema.
- EXECUTE: Performs the operation with the provided request body
  JSON.

If you need the schema, call with mode='get_request_schema' ONCE, then execute.

parameters.name: mode
parameters.description: Operation mode: 'get_request_schema' returns the OpenAPI spec for the request body, 'execute' performs the actual operation

parameters.name: request_body
parameters.description: Stringified JSON representing the request body. Required when mode is 'execute', ignored when mode is 'get_request_schema'

tools.name: GetGcpStsDelegate
tools.description:
Retrieve the Datadog-GCP STS delegate account configuration.

Use this tool to list the configured GCP STS delegate account in your Datadog account. It provides information about the integration between Datadog and Google Cloud Platform for security token service (STS) delegation.

tools.name: GetGcpUsageCostConfig
tools.description:
Retrieve specific Google Cloud Usage Cost configuration details.

The tool retrieves a specific Google Cloud Usage Cost configuration using the provided cloud account ID. It is useful for obtaining cost configurations related to Google Cloud usage in Datadog.

parameters.name: cloud_account_identifier
parameters.description: The unique identifier of the Google Cloud account for which to retrieve the usage cost configuration.

tools.name: GetHistoricalCostByOrg
tools.description:
Retrieve historical cost data across different organizations.

This tool retrieves historical cost data for multi-org and single root-org accounts from Datadog. The cost data for a given month becomes available by the 16th of the following month. Accessible only for parent-level organizations.

parameters.name: start_month_utc
parameters.description: ISO-8601 date format `[YYYY-MM]`, UTC timezone, to specify the start month for cost calculation.

parameters.name: cost_view_level
parameters.description: Specify cost breakdown level: 'summary' for parent-org or 'sub-org' for sub-org level. Defaults to 'summary'.

parameters.name: end_month

tools.name: ListAllOrganizationProcesses
tools.description:
Retrieve all processes for your organization from Datadog.

parameters.name: max_results_per_page
parameters.description: Maximum number of process results to return in one page.

parameters.description: String token to retrieve the next page of process results. Use the value from `meta.page.after` provided in the previous API response.

parameters.name: query_window_end_timestamp
parameters.description: Unix timestamp (seconds since epoch) marking the end of the query window. Defaults to 15 minutes after 'from' if not provided. If 'from' and 'to' are omitted, defaults to 15 minutes from current time.

parameters.name: query_window_start_timestamp
parameters.description: Unix timestamp marking the start of the query window. Defaults to 15 minutes before the end of the window if not provided.

parameters.name: search_string_for_processes
parameters.description: String used to search and filter processes by specific criteria.

tools.name: ListAllOrganizationUsers

parameters.name: page_number
parameters.description: The specific page number of users to return. Use for pagination.

parameters.name: page_size
parameters.description: Specifies the number of users to be returned in a single page. The maximum value allowed is 100.

parameters.name: sort_direction
parameters.description: Direction of sort for user listing. Options: 'asc' for ascending, 'desc' for descending.

parameters.name: user_filter_string
parameters.description: String to filter users by. Defaults to no filtering if blank or omitted.

parameters.name: user_status_filter

tools.name: ListApiKeys
tools.description:
Retrieve all API keys for your Datadog account.

Use this tool to fetch a list of all API keys associated with your Datadog account. It is useful for managing or auditing your API key usage.

parameters.name: api_key_filter
parameters.description: String to filter API keys by specified criteria. Use it to narrow down the list based on specific string matches.

parameters.name: created_after_date_filter
parameters.description: Include API keys created on or after this date. Expected format: YYYY-MM-DD.

parameters.name: filter_api_keys_by_category
parameters.description: Filter API keys by the specified category.

parameters.name: filter_by_remote_config_read_enabled
parameters.description: Set to true to filter API keys with remote config read enabled; false otherwise.

parameters.name: filter_created_before_date
parameters.description: Include only API keys created on or before this date in the format YYYY-MM-DD.

parameters.name: include_related_resources
parameters.description: Comma-separated list of resource paths (`created_by`, `modified_by`) to include related data in the response.

parameters.name: modified_after_date_filter
parameters.description: Specify a date to include API keys modified on or after this date. Use YYYY-MM-DD format.

parameters.name: modified_before_date
parameters.description: Include API keys modified on or before this specified date. Format should be YYYY-MM-DD.

parameters.name: page_size
parameters.description: Specifies the number of API keys returned in a single page; maximum value is 100.

parameters.name: sort_by_attribute
parameters.description: Attribute to sort API keys by. Use a minus sign for descending order.

parameters.name: specific_page_number_to_return
parameters.description: The specific page number to return from the paginated list of API keys.

parameters.description: Include application keys created on or after this date (YYYY-MM-DD).

parameters.name: created_before_date
parameters.description: Filters application keys created on or before this date. Expected format is YYYY-MM-DD.

parameters.name: filter_application_keys
parameters.description: Filter the application keys based on a specified string to narrow down the results.

parameters.name: include_related_resource
parameters.description: Specify 'owned_by' to include related resource information in the response.

parameters.name: page_number

parameters.description: Specify the number of application keys to return per page. Maximum is 100.

parameters.name: sort_keys_by_attribute

Retrieve a list of all apps with optional filters and sorting.

parameters.name: filter_by_app_name

parameters.name: filter_by_query
parameters.description: Filter apps by the app name or the app creator's name.

parameters.description: Filter apps by specifying tags. Separate multiple tags with commas.

parameters.name: filter_self_service_enabled
parameters.description: Filter apps by self-service enablement. True for enabled, false otherwise.

parameters.name: include_published_apps
parameters.description: Set to true to include only published apps, false to exclude them.

parameters.name: page_number
parameters.description: The page number to return for paginated results.

parameters.name: page_size
parameters.description: The number of apps to return per page.

parameters.name: show_only_favorite_apps
parameters.description: Set to true to filter and show only apps that you have marked as favorites.

parameters.name: sort_fields_and_directions

parameters.description: Specify the earliest time for the events you want to retrieve. Use a timestamp string.

parameters.description: Specify the maximum number of CI test events to return in the response.

parameters.name: max_timestamp
parameters.description: Specify the maximum timestamp for the requested events.

parameters.name: minimum_timestamp
parameters.description: The minimum timestamp to filter requested events. Format is typically ISO 8601.

parameters.name: pagination_cursor
parameters.description: Cursor for fetching the next set of paginated results, provided by the previous query.

parameters.name: search_query
parameters.description: Search query using log syntax to filter CI Visibility test events.

parameters.name: sort_order
parameters.description: Specify the order of events by using 'timestamp' for ascending or '-timestamp' for descending.

parameters.name: pagination_cursor

tools.name: ListDatastoreItems

Retrieve items from a specified datastore.

parameters.description: The unique identifier for the datastore from which to fetch items.

parameters.name: item_limit_per_page
parameters.description: Limit the number of items to return per page for pagination. Maximum of 100 items per page.

parameters.name: pagination_offset
parameters.description: Specifies the number of items to skip from the beginning of the result set for pagination.

Retrieve Fastly services for a specific account.

tools.name: ListFindings
tools.description:
Retrieve a list of security findings from Datadog.

Use this tool to obtain a list of security findings, including misconfigurations and identity risks from Datadog. You can apply filters to customize the search results and include additional details by specifying parameters. The response includes summary details of each finding along with pagination metadata.

parameters.name: filter_by_evaluation_change_date
parameters.description: Specify a date (Unix ms) or date range (using comparison operators) to find results altered from pass to fail or vice versa.

parameters.name: filter_by_resource_id
parameters.description: Return only findings for the specified resource ID.

parameters.name: filter_by_resource_type
parameters.description: Return findings only for the specified resource type. Use to narrow down results to specific resource types, such as 'aws', 'gcp', etc.

parameters.name: filter_by_rule_id
parameters.description: Provide a specific rule ID to filter findings related to that rule.

parameters.name: filter_by_rule_name
parameters.description: Specify the rule name to return findings associated with it. This filters findings based on the provided rule name.

parameters.name: filter_by_tags
parameters.description: Specify tags to filter findings. Use the format `tag_key:tag_value`. Supports multiple tags separated by commas.

parameters.name: filter_discovery_timestamp
parameters.description: Return findings discovered at a specific time (Unix ms) or within a date range using comparison operators (e.g., `>`, `<=`).

parameters.name: filter_evaluation_status
parameters.description: Specify to return only findings that are either 'pass' or 'fail'.

parameters.name: include_detailed_findings
parameters.description: Set to true to retrieve additional fields like external ID, description, and IP addresses for some findings.

parameters.name: max_findings_limit
parameters.description: Set the maximum number of findings to return, up to a limit of 1000.

parameters.name: next_page_cursor
parameters.description: Use this to return the next page of findings starting from this cursor's position.

parameters.name: return_muted_findings
parameters.description: Set to `true` to return muted findings. Set to `false` to exclude them.

parameters.name: snapshot_timestamp
parameters.description: Specify the Unix timestamp (in milliseconds) to get findings for a specific snapshot of time.

parameters.name: status_filter
parameters.description: Specify the status of findings to return: critical, high, medium, low, or info.

parameters.name: vulnerability_type_filters
parameters.description: A list of strings to filter findings by matching vulnerability types. Repeatable for multiple types.

parameters.name: page_size

documentationChunks.content:
<Callout type="info">
**Required environment variables:** `DATADOG_API_KEY`, `DATADOG_APPLICATION_KEY`, `DATADOG_BASE_URL`
</Callout>

The Arcade Datadog API MCP Server requires three environment variables to authenticate with the [Datadog API](https://docs.datadoghq.com/api/latest/):

- `DATADOG_API_KEY`
- `DATADOG_APPLICATION_KEY`
- `DATADOG_BASE_URL`

**How to obtain your credentials:**

- Log in to your [Datadog dashboard](https://app.datadoghq.com/).
- Navigate to **Organization Settings** (click your profile icon in the bottom left).
- Go to **API Keys** and create a new key (provide a name and click **Create Key**).
- Go to **Application Keys** and create a new key (provide a name and click **Create Key**).
- Determine your **Base URL** based on your Datadog site (check the URL in your browser):
  - US1: `api.datadoghq.com`
  - US3: `api.us3.datadoghq.com`
  - US5: `api.us5.datadoghq.com`
  - EU1: `api.datadoghq.eu`
  - AP1: `api.ap1.datadoghq.com`
  - GOV: `api.ddog-gov.com`

<Callout type="warning">
**Warning:** Keep `DATADOG_API_KEY` and `DATADOG_APPLICATION_KEY` secret. Do not commit these values to source control or expose them in logs.
</Callout>

For more details, see the [Datadog API and Application Keys documentation](https://docs.datadoghq.com/account_management/api-app-keys/).

summary:
The Arcade toolkit for DatadogApi empowers developers to interact seamlessly with the Datadog API to manage monitoring, analytics, and incident responses. This toolkit enhances the ability to automate workflows, streamline operations, and effectively manage cloud resources.

**Capabilities**:
- Efficiently manage Datadog integrations, monitor resources, and handle alerts.
- Automate operational workflows, including on-call management and incident response.
- Support configuration management for AWS, Azure, and GCP services.
- Streamline security monitoring and logging capabilities.
- Facilitate role and permissions management across teams.

**Secrets**:
- Configuration includes various secrets like `DATADOG_API_KEY`, `DATADOG_APPLICATION_KEY`, and others essential for API access.
